div.p:
1. V: Friday. Dr Morse called this Morning at my Office— He has been the last Summer, upon a mission partly from the Society for propagating the gospel in foreign parts, and partly from the Government of the United States, among our North-western tribes of Indians, and is here to make his report to the
Department of War. He is occupied also upon the publication of a new Edition of his Geography, and wished for some information respecting the boundaries claimed by the United States. I told him that our boundary was not definitively settled, and the definition of it in the new Edition of his book must depend on the final determination of Spain upon the Florida Treaty— If that should be ratified, our Southern, and South-western boundary would be defined from the gulph of Mexico to the South-Sea— Should Spain refuse the ratification our Southern boundary would remain as it has been, unsettled— Our claim was to the Rio Bravo del Norte, the course of which I shewed him on the antient maps which we have at the Department— And I referred him to my discussion of the title with Mr Onis in 1818— I also referred him to the Convention of 20. October 1818 with Great-Britain for the Northern and North-western Boundary. He made enquiries also concerning returns of the Census, and whether he could be furnished with abstracts from them before they should be reported to Congress, which they cannot be till the next Session. I told him it was doubtful whether I could allow this. I thought the official Report, must first be made to Congress. He recommended one of his Sons, for any assistance that I may want to make abstracts from the returns of manufactures— Mr James Barbour, a Senator from Virginia, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations of the Senate came to ask for communications relating to them. I gave him a summary of them, and promised to send him the most material despatches from Messrs.Gallatin, Rush and Forsyth— Mr Butler member of the House of Representatives from Louisiana came to recommend J. W. Smith for District Attorney, in that State— I dined at the Presidents in company with the Diplomatic Corps, and several members of both Houses of Congress— The arrangement of the foreign Ministers at my recommendation was—Mr Canning, as the last arrived, at the right and Mr Poletica, the eldest accredited Minister of his rank, at the left hand of the President. Genl. Vives the Spanish Minister at the right of Mr Canning—The subalterns of the foreign diplomacy, to find their places where they could— The President asked me to take the seat at the centre of the table opposite to him, and to ask the members of the Senate to sit by me— I accordingly asked Mr King of New-York, and Mr Burrill of Rhode-Island— The dinner like most diplomatic entertainments was grave and stately. I came home before 8 O’Clock .

2. VI: In the early parts of the Session of Congress, both houses are in the practice of making holidays of the Saturday, by adjourning over from Friday to Monday. There are therefore always on those days numerous visitors at the public offices— I had this day S. W. Dana and R. M. Johnson of the Senate— H. W. Edwards, Mark L. Hill and William Hendricks, members of the House, and Solomon Sibley, the delegate from the territory of Michigan, who brought me a Letter from the late delegate Woodbridge— Edwards came to enquire whether a new appointment would be made of a district Attorney in Connecticut, or whether the present Attorney—Hezekiah Huntington would be nominated for re-appointment. His Commission will expire in a few weeks— Edwards said he had no complaint to make against Huntington, nor any objection to state against his re-appointment; but if another person was to be appointed he should wish to present the name of one, whom he could pledge himself to be in every respect perfectly well qualified for the office— I told him I did not know, what were the President’s intentions, in this matter; but if they should be not to renominate Huntington, he Edwards should have notice, in time to recommend the person to whom he now alluded— I observed that the rule of the President with regard to all Offices, which expired by limitation, was to re-nominate the same officer, unless there were special circumstances requiring a change. Whether they existed in this case, I did not know, perhaps the President might— Mr Hill came for some information, respecting the progress of the Commissioners under the fifth Article of the Treaty of Ghent— He spoke also something of general politics— Hill is a man of moderate character and good dispositions—without much energy. Dana, has been more than twenty years in succession a member of Congress—but this is his last Session. His time of service, expires with this Congress, and a successor has already been chosen to supply his place in the next. He
is a man of talents and integrity, of cheerful humour and pleasant manners, a little tinged with levity, and a little addicted to flattery. His Conversation is amusing, and he has wit and humour— His manner is to treat every thing apparently in joke. He came now to make some enquiries about expenditures in the public offices— Hendricks came to recommend the re-appointment of John Vawter, as Marshal for the District of Indiana. There have been complaints against him, which he appears to have repelled; but the President has not yet decided to renominate him. Coll. R. M. Johnson came with an order from C. S. Todd who was appointed to go last Spring to Venezuela, but who has yet reached no further than the Island of Margarita. Todd asks for a translator, or interpreter, or to come home in the Spring. Dr. Morse dined with us, and went to spend the Evening at Mr Calhoun’s.

3. III:15. The winter is setting in with severity. I heard a Mr Jennings preach at the Capitol, and afterwards paid a number of visits. To N. Edwards and Freeman Walker, Senators from Illinois and Georgia lodging at Mrs Peyton’s— Edwards is still afflicted with the influenza, which continues to prevail almost universally. I have it yet myself, slightly, with the ordinary symptoms only of a cold, but with the peculiarity that it seems to be intermitting; occasionally disappearing for three or four days and then returning. Walker is a young man, and enjoys a high reputation for abilities and integrity. He has also a handsome person, and pleasing deportment. Edwards says that in the party controversies of Georgia, which are exceedingly violent, Walker is neutral. The heads of the two parties, are Mr Crawford the Secretary of the Treasury, and John Clark, Governor of Georgia. Clark and Crawford have fought one duel, in which Crawford was wounded in the left hand. About two months since Clark published a pamphlet containing a history of the feud between him and Crawford which is of nearly twenty years standing— The narrative exhibits Crawford in the most odious light; as sacrificing every principle to his ambition, and states a series of facts supported by documents, so very disadvantageous to Crawford’s character, that it seemed to require an answer— None however has yet appeared— Clark complains that at the duel, Crawford, countenanced by his second, refused to take another shot, merely because his left hand was disabled; and that he afterwards declined fighting him on a second Challenge. As Crawford had already killed one man in a duel, these refusals to fight are more to his credit than his disadvantage— But the whole tissue of his conduct towards Clark, as stated in the pamphlet has been altogether unjustifiable. He proves, beyond reasonable doubt, that the attack upon General Jackson, and through him upon me; in the affair of the Seminole War, was commenced, organized, and instigated by Crawford. But he more than insinuates that Crawford was concerned with the Indian agent Mitchell in smuggling African Slaves into Georgia, from Amelia Island— This I totally disbelieve— The pamphlet has produced an effect unfavourable to Crawford’s reputation as a man, and the present state of the Treasury does him no credit as a financier— His friends however are numerous, persevering, and well trained to political intrigue— Edwards thinks that Walker will be at the head of a third party in Georgia. I also visited at Georgetown H. G. Otis, Senator from Massachusetts, R. King from New-York, and B. Gorham the new member from Boston, in the room of Jonathan Mason resigned— They all lodge at the Hotel at Georgetown.

4. III:30. This was a rainy day, and I had as visitors at the office only William Lee, and E. Wyer. My office hours were spent in the library, weighing various samples of wheat, the Washington City weights, and the water containable in the French Litre. The experiments with the wheat, are not entirely satisfactory. The weight of the kernels differ from 30 to 50 to a penny-weight Troy,
and the specific gravity of the kernels is not exactly in proportion to their bulk. The corporation of the city of Washington lately sent Leonard the Sealer of weights and Measures to Baltimore to compare and correct them by the standards there. Their avoirdupois pound weighed only 6970 grains Troy—and was therefore 30 grains too light— He has now brought it back plumbed, and weighing ten grains too much, or 7010 grains— The two pound weight is 24 grains and the four pound 62 grains too heavy. My principal object however this day was to ascertain the weight and cubical contents of the French litre— Hassler brought from France two standard brass Kilogrammes, and two litres of the same metal, made by Fortin—One of each of which has been lent me from the Department of War— The Kilogramme weighs 15435 grains Troy, which is three grains less than my Kilogramme in a nest; which I brought from Paris. The French Litre is by Law a cylindrical vessel of 86 millimetres diameter and 172 Millimetres depth— Assuming Captain Katers admeasurement of the Metre as correct and taking it for 39.37079 inches English—then the diameter of the Litre is 3.386 inches, and its depth 6.772 inches— Its cubical contents then must be 60.979. inches, which may with all possible accuracy be set down for 61— Now the Brass Litre Modele, made by Fortin, measured with all possible attention upon Troughton’s scale was 3.4167 inches in diameter and 6.6710 inches deep— Its contents thus are 61.1637 inches—the diameter being more and the depth less than perfect accuracy would require, and the result giving about 1/6 of a cubic inch, more than the standard— This Litre, filled with rain water, at the temperature of 40 degrees of Fahrenheit’s thermometer; being precisely that of its greatest density, and the atmosphere of the room being at the same time at 45. contained 15402 grains Troy of Water—to which two additions are to be made—one of 19 grains for the weight of the air contained in the Litre when weighed before filling it with water, and the other of 8 grains, for additional weight of the water at 10 of Reaumur or 54 1/2 of Fahrenheit, being the temperature at which the Litre is to contain an exact Kilogramme— With these allowances Fortin’s Litre contains 15429 grains Troy, of rain water; which is 6 grains less than the standard Kilogrammes brought by Hassler, 9 grains less than my Kilogramme, and 16 grains less than its weight as compared with the old pound poids de Mare— My result makes the apparent specific gravity of my rain water 252 1/2 grains Troy to the cubical inch. These experiments must be more than once repeated.

5. III:15.Mr. Mark Langdon Hill, a member of the house of Representatives from Maine called at my house—this gentleman intimates a friendly disposition to me, and occasionally shews me curious Letters. Mrs. Adams attended the funeral of Columbia Peter, a beautiful and amiable young woman, daughter of Thomas Peter of Georgetown. She died at the house of Mrs Lewisher mother’s Sister, where she was upon a visit—after an illness of only three or four days— She was only 19 or 20 years old, and had every appearance of blooming health and a vigorous Constitution. Mrs Peter her mother is a granddaughter of Mrs Washington, by her first husband Mr Custis.— This event has cast a gloom upon the City— It was not known that she was ill, until the tidings came of her death, and it was like a sudden and unexpected calamity. Miss Fanny Johnson of Frederick came here to spend a short time with Mrs Adams. She is a Granddaughter of the late Governor Thomas Johnson, the brother of my wife’s father— Fanny Johnson having lost both her Parents lives with her aunt Mrs Grahame at Frederick— Mrs Adams paid them a visit last Summer, and then invited this young lady to come and visit her this winter. Major Grahame her uncle came with her, but lodges at Georgetown— She is about twenty-two years, old and uncommonly beautiful— Mr Grahame was here this Evening, at the weekly tea-party, which was numerously attended— Mrs Adams bespoke an evening party, and oyster-supper at her kinsman T. Cook’s.

6. VI: Morning visits to Mr Lanman, a Senator from Connecticut— Storrs and Allen members of the House of Representatives from New-York, and Cannon from Tennessee— None of whom being at their lodgings, I left Cards— The family spent this Evening at Captain Thompson’s. He was formerly of the Marine Corps and his wife is daughter to Coll. Burroughs, once its commander— Thompson is now chief Clerk in the third Auditor’s Office: his daughter Cecilia, is an acquaintance and friend of Fanny Johnson’s— I was suffering with the influenza cough, and did not go— The Resolution reported by the Committee of the Senate for the admission of the State of Missouri, into the Union, was this day before that body for Consideration when Mr Eaton, a Senator from Tennessee offered a proviso by way of amendment; that the admission is not to be understood as giving the assent of Congress, to any Article in the Constitution of Missouri, if any such there be, repugnant to the Article in the Constitution of the United States, which entitles the Citizens of each state to the rights of Citizens in the other States.

7. III:15.Mr Lynch, and Dr. Morse were at the Office— The House of Representatives, last Monday on the motion of Mr Fuller of Massachusetts, passed a Resolution, instructing the Committee of Commerce to enquire into the expediency of taking measures for obtaining the free admission of our Commerce to the Navigation of the Black Sea— Mr Lynch told me that as this Resolution would necessarily make public whatever should hereafter be done in pursuance of it, he concluded there would no longer be any prospect of success for his project of disposing of his Steam-ship, and he had therefore given it up altogether. Dr. Morse is yet making enquiries for the new Edition of his Geography, and inquisitive about our boundaries— I advised him to postpone his definition of them till we shall have ascertained whether the Florida Treaty will be ratified or not— We had company to dine with us, chiefly members of Congress. Messrs.Gaillard, President of the Senate, pro Tem. David Holmes of Mississippi, W. R. King of Alabama, and H. G. Otis of Massachusetts, Senators. J. W. Taylor, Speaker of the House of Representatives, Messrs:Abbot, of Georgia, Baldwin of Pennsylvania, Cocke of Tennessee, Folger of Massachusetts, Meech of Vermont, Newton of Virginia, Plumer of New Hampshire, Simkins of South Carolina, and Tracy of New York, members of the House, and Mr Grahame— In the Evening we attended a Ball at Mr Thompson’s the Secretary of the Navy— Mrs. Thompson was a Livingston— They have two daughters Catherine and Louisa, both comely and accomplished. The crowd at the Ball was great. I had a conversation with Mr Canning upon some of the Orators and Statesmen of Great-Britain in which I advanced some opinions, which he thought paradoxical. Both Houses of Congress were this day debating upon the Missouri question— In the Senate the Amendment proposed by Mr Eaton was rejected by a vote of 24 to 21.— The Resolution for Admission then passed to the third reading.

8. VI:Mr Rice a baptist clergyman came this morning to solicit a subscription from me to a project which he, and Obadiah Brown, another Baptist Clergyman, and a Clerk in the Treasury Department and since others have set on foot, which they call the Columbian Society for literary purposes, but which from the plan as exhibited to me, seemed more entitled to the denomination of a Society for purposes of individual benefit to the projectors— The Scheme includes a School, a University, a Theological Institution, and a Church— I declined subscribing, on the principle that I considered the plan too extensive for the circumstances and prospects of this place, and that money, given for an object of which the end was so disproportioned to the means would not be usefully bestowed. This was a delicate and disagreeable communication to make; but in the public situation, that I occupy scarcely a week passes without bringing its subscription paper. I make it a rule
to subscribe in every case the object of which I do not absolutely disapprove. This makes it necessary to assign my reasons when I decline— Dr Morse called again at the Office— He is about to return to New-Haven— The Dr is a man of considerable ability, cramped and trammeled by a vicious religious education— He was born and educated in Connecticut, but more than thirty years ago, was settled as a Minister at Charlestown, Massachusetts. Bred to the most straightest sect of the Calvinistic creed, he has drilled his faith in special providences to aquiescence of mind in the grossest absurdities— Living in the immediate vicinity of Boston, whether the fashion of Religion has of late been running to an opposite excess, he has more than once been drawn into controversy and like all religious polemics has displayed an intolerant temper. At the same time he has taken in the things of this world an interest deeper than the general opinion indulges to persons of the clerical profession— He has devoted the leisure of his life chiefly to Geography. Before his settlement at Charlestown he had published a volume of American Geography with encouraging success. Many Editions of this work have since been published, and every revisal gives him a new copy-right— He has also thrown it into various forms, sometimes by turning it into a Gazetteer, and sometimes reducing it to an abridgment— He also associated with another Clergyman, a Religious and political fanatic by the name of Parish, in publishing an abridged History of New-England, intended for a school-book. But its old woman’s tales of special providences were too ridiculous— All these labours had a direct eye to profit, but they did not withdraw the Doctor from the religious field— He commenced and carried on a War against the Unitarians of Boston, till he found his own Congregation deserting and taking part against him— Some of them went off and built a new Church where they settled a Minister with a different Creed. With the remnant he fell into questions about his Salary, and finally parted from them last year, I fear without being desired. He returned to his primitive residence at New Haven, and has become a missionary among the Indians. He is a man of indefatigable industry, and if his religion were more liberal, or his practice less worldly minded would present a more consistent and even a more respectable character— Mr Brent was absent this day from the Office— Major Grahame was here; and we all spent the Evening and had an oyster-supper at Mr T. Cook’s— Mr and Mrs Frye, and Mr & Mrs. W. S. Smith were there— My influenza cough was very troublesome.

9. VI. I repeated my experiments in the Library of the Department upon the weight of Water containable in the French Standard Litre— Fahrenheits Thermometer stood in the room at 50. I had several buckets brought filled with River Water at 40. Rain Water at 46 and Pump Water at 54. Neither of them was therefore at the temperature of the atmosphere in the room— The river Water was no doubt of the temperature of the atmosphere where it was drawn, and the rain of that where it had fallen— The pump water was several degrees warmer. The Litre is a cylinder of polished brass of an inch thick, the edge round its upper border being perfectly flat. There is with it a disk of ground glass of diameter just more than that of the outer edge of the Litre. In filling the vessel, by the natural property of fluids the liquor forms a convex surface at the top, rising at the centre before it overflows at the borders— When thus full, without overflow the glass disk is slided over the top of the Litre, entirely covering it, and excluding every bubble of air. The vessel then through the transparent glass disk looks to the eye as if it were empty, but such is the cohesion of the water to the glass, that the Litre with its contents weighing upwards of seven pounds Troy weight may be lifted by the edges of the glass disk alone, without separating from it. I first weighed in the Scales the Litre itself, with the glass disk and found them weigh 4 Pounds 6 ounces 12 pennyweight 8 grains
Troy— Then leaving those balancing weights in the scale, after filling the Litre with Water, I added weights to balance it, and thus found that it contained 15400 grains of rain, 15404 grains of Pump, and 15405 grains of river water— The principal remark I make on this result is of the very slight difference between the specific gravity of the different kinds of water. The next is that the weight falls short of what it ought to be, even with the allowances made for the weight of the air expelled from the Litre by filling it with water. A third is some distrust with regard to the perfect accuracy of the Scales. I am satisfied that the beam ought not to be entirely loose; for sometimes when the Scales appear to be perfectly balanced, and addition of ten or fifteen grains in one of them will fail to turn it, when half a grain ought to be sufficient to bring it down. I broke one of my thermometers this day in wiping it after using it to prove the temperature of the water in the buckets. Evening at home.

10. VI: Heard at the Capitol Mr Campbell the Chaplain to the House of Representatives, preach Luke XVI:31. “And he said unto him, if they hear not Moses and the prophets, neither will they be persuaded, though one rose from the dead.” He is not without eloquence, but to such an Audience as the Chaplains of Congress must be supposed to have for hearers, the Sermon ought rather to be a didactic than a pathetic discourse. And if extemporaneous appeals to the feelings, are more powerful than those that are studied, moral instruction must be the better for meditation and precision. This text opens profound views of human nature— The parable of which it forms a part is one of the most remarkable passages in the gospels. The conclusion from the argument of the parable, would seem to be that the mission of Christ himself was useless— Suppose one of the Pharisees to whom the discourse was addressed had said in reply—“Thou bearest witness against thyself— If Moses and the prophets are sufficient for securing the joys of Paradise in the world to come— If they who believe not Moses and the prophets would not be persuaded though one should rise from the dead, why comest thou with a voice as of one from the dead? And how can those believe thee, who would not believe one from the dead?[”] The answer to this obvious, and as it appears, to me powerful objection, would give one of the best opportunities to descant upon the true character of Christ, and of his mission— The basis of the argument would be that the voice of Christ was more than that of one from the dead—that the objects of his mission were not only to give clearer ideas of the future world than had been disclosed to Moses and the prophets, but to improve the condition of mankind in this world, independent of its connection with the next. A parallel between the force of evidence resulting from the voice of an apparition from the dead and that of the Christian revelation would belong to the subject. But it is doubtful whether such a view of it could be taken by an extemporaneous discourse. Mr Campbell took of it a quite different— He applied to the gospel itself that which Christ supposes Abraham to have said of the disbelief of Moses and the prophets, and reasoned upon the broad position, that they who will not believe the scriptures would resist even the evidence of a messenger from the dead. A more superficial, but I think less correct doctrine than that which properly flows from the parable. Mr Isham Talbot, a Senator from Kentucky, elected in the place of W. Logan resigned, paid us a visit. We had Company to dinner—Major Grahame, Mr D. P. Cook of Illinois, Dr Huntt, Mr T. Cook, Mr and Mrs Frye, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith— Major Grahame is to return to-morrow or the next day to Frederick. We have by much persuasion prevailed upon Fanny Johnson, who intended to have returned with him, to stay and spend some weeks with us.

11. IV: My influenza cough is yet very severe; especially in the morning immediately after I rise— It was this morning violent and long continued. I this day finished the reading of the manuscript of the secret Journals of the Old Congress, to be sent to Wait at Boston for publication— There will be four Volumes, and I have thought it necessary to go through the examination of all the copy, myself. It
has of course absorbed much time— Mr Bates the Delegate from the Arkansas territory was at the Office—two or three judges for that territory have been appointed, upon allegations that they were going to settle there, and urgent solicitations from their friends— They have accepted the appointments and received the Salaries, to the last hour that they could, and never went to the Territory, or never held a Court there— One of them even wrote to me last Spring requesting me to consider him as resigning his Commission after the fourth of July; that he might be enabled to receive until then the Salary of the Office without performing any of its duties— The last appointment was of a Mr Thompson of Ohio, who for six Months has neither accepted nor declined— The President is embarrassed whether to nominate him to the Senate; his commission having issued during the recess of the Senate; or to pass him over and nominate another— The Territory has by this scandalous management; been nearly two years without any organized judiciary, of which their legislature have complained by a memorial to the Congress— Bates now recommends a resident of the territory; but Coll. R. M. Johnson wishes the appointment of a brother of his own— E. Wyer also was at the Office— The President has determined that he shall be sent to Hayti; and the arrangements are to be made for despatching him. We spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s, with a small party— I met there a Mr Nelson, a member elect of the next Congress for the Frederick District, in Maryland, a son of Roger Nelson who was several years a member from the same district— This young man is a lawyer and married Harriet Burroughs the youngest daughter of the late Coll. Burroughs. I played Chess this Evening with Mrs. C. Freeman. The Senate this day by a vote of 26 to 18 passed the Resolution for admitting the State of Missouri, with the amendment proposed by Mr Eaton which they had rejected on the 7th. but which they this day adopted— After they had agreed to it, Mr Macon of North-Carolina, moved that the Resolution should be recommitted with instructions to the Committee to strike it out—this motion was rejected by a vote of 17 to 27. and the resolution itself past, by 26 to 18. The change of the majority upon Eaton’s proviso since last Thursday must have been effected, out of doors.

12. VI:15.Major Grahame returned to Frederick. Mr Crawford the Secretary of the Treasury called at the Office, to enquire the amount of unexpended balances remaining of the appropriations of preceding years of the several funds the expenditure of which is under the superintendence of the Department of State; which were accordingly given to him— Mr Edward Jones of Boston, late one of the Collectors of the Internal taxes also came. He is here for the settlement of his accounts, and in expectation of the passage of a Bankrupt Act applies to be appointed one of the Commissioners. He complains that his former Office was laborious odious and unprofitable. Of the land tax, there were a great multitude of charges of ten cents, and 6 1/4 cents each, requiring reiterated applications for payment, correspondences, receipts and even suits at Law, for all which the only compensation allowed him was a small per centage— His chance for the passage of the Bankrupt Act, is slender— I repeated the experiments to ascertain the weight in water of the contents of the French Litre— The Buckets of Water having remained in the Library Rooms, several days were all of the same temperature as the atmosphere of the room; 38 by Fahrenheit— I found the Vessel and glass this day weigh 26212 grains, or four grains less than they had weighed last Saturday. The Pump water held by the vessel now weighed 15408 grains, four more than on Saturday. The rain water 15405. or five grains more, but the river water only 15389 grains, or 16 grains less than on Saturday— For this last result there must have been some error in the operation— There is an aptitude in making experiments, and a familiarity with the instruments employed essential to the accurate making of them, and the want of which I now perceive— Whether the difference
between the weight of the Litre and glass, on Saturday and this day was owing to the difference in the temperature of the atmosphere, or to some inaccuracy then or now in the weighing. I am unable to determine— The process of weighing is tedious, for the vibration of the balance at the addition or deduction of every grain or half grains takes several minutes to settle into its poise— There was a fall of Snow this day, the first for the Season here; though South of this place at Richmond, and at Norfolk in Virginia, there fell about ten inches the first of this Month— Mrs Adams had her weekly tea-party this Evening—

13. VI:15. I called at the Navy Department this Morning and saw the Chief Clerk B. Homans, about the payment of a Bill of Exchange sent me by E. Cruft of Boston. Homans lent me a Letter from G. B. English, a young man of very eccentric character who has been a Lieutenant in our Navy, but quitted it to enter the service of the Bashaw of Egypt— He had a predisposition to it in a turn of mind which induced him several years ago to write a book against the Christian religion. He was answered by several persons, and among the rest by Edward Everett, to whom he in this Letter threatens to give a tremendous castigation in a reply, which he will send to England for publication— It had been reported that this young man had become a professed Mahometan— In this Letter he feebly defends himself against that charge— He professes to have assumed the turban only in the legitimate pursuit of Fortune, and he avows very laudable sentiments both of patriotism, and of family affection. He speaks with suitable feeling at his mothers deep anxiety and distress under the evil reports which his conduct has brought upon him; and soothes her with a picture of brilliant prospects before him. He also holds out expectations of being instrumental in preparing the way for a commercial Treaty between the United States and the Sultan— I next called at the War Office upon Major Roberdeau, who is measuring the French Metres upon Troughton’s Scale. He promised to procure me some distilled Water, to try again the weight contained in the Litre. Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy came to the Office, and told me that Mr Cruft’s bill could not be paid by advance of time, for want of an appropriation. Mr Leonard the Sealer of weights and measures of the City left his new Standards here. The dry measures half-bushel peck and half-peck are of copper, lined with tin—new, but very coarsely made, and much less correct than the old ones— I measured them to ascertain their cubical dimensions, and weighed them, filled with Water, in Commodore Rogers’s Scales. The old measures were all correct in proportion to the Winchester Bushel— Of the new measures, the Peck only is exact; the half-bushel being too small and the half-pack too large— The Scales are good; but loaded with weights of forty pounds and upwards, quantities of less than an ounce will scarcely turn the Scales. It is always a speculation what such large Scales with Troy weights of ten, twenty and thirty Pounds could be going to Sir John Warren, while Commander of a British Squadron. They were apparently intended to be used for avoirdupois weights, and carry with them presumptive evidence of fraud intended somewhere. We attended this Evening the Drawing Room at the President’s.

14. VI:30.Dr Eustis called on me this Morning at the Office. The question upon the Resolution for admitting the State of Missouri, without condition into the Union was taken yesterday in the House of Representatives and rejected by a vote of 93 to 79. Eustis had made a speech against the Resolution the day before. He now intends to bring forward his proposition, for her admission ipso facto upon her expunging from her Constitution the Article which is repugnant to that of the United States— But it is doubtful whether this will meet the views of either party; being too much for the Slave party, and not enough for the others. He has also great apprehensions of the use which the federal party wish to make of this question. Mr Torres the Chargé d’Affaires from the so styled Colombian Republic came and brought a number of papers relating to his Government, and his mission— Among the rest, was a manuscript map, of the water communication, actually existing, between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, across the Isthmus of
Panama— Mr Torres renews his applications for a supply of muskets, and to that now adds another for a loan of money. He complained that by the interposition of the Government of the Netherlands, a loan which the Colombians were successfully negotiating in Holland had been defeated, and he spoke loosely and indefinitely of some supposed secret Treaty of the Congress at Aix-la-Chapelle against the South-Americans— As I was on my return from my Office to my house to dine, I met on the Steps of the outer door of the Department an old man, whose countenance struck me, as if I had seen him before— He enquired if I could tell him whether the Secretary of State was at his office— On my answering that I was myself the person, he held out his hand, saying, Mr Adams, I am very glad to see you— While he was speaking I recognized him for Commodore Samuel Tucker, with whom in the Months of February and March 1778 I went to France in the Frigate Boston of which he was then Commander. I immediately addressed him by name, and invited him to go home and dine with me; but he had dined. He will come to-morrow— He was chosen one of the Electors of President and Vice President for the State of Maine, of which he is now an inhabitant, and was then appointed by the Electors to bring their votes on to this City— He has at this Season travelled nearly seven hundred miles in a week, at an age of at least 75. It will be forty-three years next April since I parted from him at Bordeaux— I have no recollection of having seen him from that day to this— He says that about the year 1792 or 1793 he called for a few minutes at the Office which I then kept in Court Street Boston; but this had escaped my memory— I spent this Evening with my family at W. S. Smith’s. Played Chess.

15. VII:Mr Holmes one of the Senators from the new State of Maine, came to the Office, with Mr Joseph Dane, the Representative of the District, of which Holmes was the member before his recent translation to the Senate. I was at the Presidents and informed him of the Communications yesterday received from Mr Torres. As to his applications for muskets and for a loan of money, he has long since been informed that the Executive of the United States cannot grant them, without an Act of Congress, and that they could not be granted at-all without a breach of neutrality— But the motive of Torres, is to keep himself in credit with his own Constituents for his zeal— Every application makes a despatch— The President directed to have a copy of the map shewing the water communication between the two seas, taken, at the Engineer Office in the War Department— Commodore Tucker, and a young Mr Breckenridge dined with us— The latter lately brought me a Letter of introduction from Genl. Peter B. Porter who married his sister, the widow Grayson. The old Commodore was in high Spirits, fought all his battles oer again, and told me much of his history since the War of the Revolution— It has not been fortunate— He lost all the hard-earned fruits of his of his revolutionary services, by the failure of a man to whom he had lent it. The man no sooner had the money than he absconded, and Tucker never saw him again till after an interval of more than thirty years, he met him at Portland, as a member of the Convention, which lately made the Constitution for the State of Maine— And he then had nothing. By this disaster Tucker was himself obliged to abandon his residence, and remove from Massachusetts down to a small landed Estate in the District of Maine where he has been many years living in a log-house and on a scanty farm— He is now the only surviving Officer of his rank, who served through the whole revolutionary War; and there was not one Officer, who served with more effect in that War— He was admitted this day within the body of the House of Representatives under the rule which admits all persons who have received the thanks of Congress— I went with the family this Evening to a concert given by a musical family named Lewis; a man with four children from four to twelve years of age, all of whom excel as musical performers; on the Violin, Piano, Harp and Clarinett— There is nothing interesting in the performance, except the age of the children.

16. V:30. Saturday, and Congress not being in Session, there came as usual to the Office several members of the House of Representatives— Mr Holmes the Senator from Maine came to borrow a map made by Mr Bradley the Agent under the 5th Article of the Treaty of Ghent, and upon which is marked the line of
division due North from the source of the St. Croix river to the highlands. Mr Holmes is desirous of having a copy of this map— Mr Baldwin of Pennsylvania came and introduced Mr T. G. M’Cullough a new member from that State, chosen in the room of David Fullerton, resigned. Mr Hutchins G. Burton a member from North Carolina came to request that through Mr Rush certain information might be sought concerning a claim of a person in that State upon the British Government for a pension. John Sergeant one of the members from Philadelphia came to recommend a person for the appointment of Consul at the Havanna— I was at the President’s— There have been within these few days rumours circulated from paragraphs in the Newspapers coming from England, that the Florida Treaty has been ratified by Spain. This morning there was in the National Intelligencer a paragraph from the Charleston S.C. Times, an Extract of a Letter to a person in that City, from Liverpool, dated 26. October, quoting from a Letter received the day before from Samuel Williams at London, the following words—“My correspondent at Madrid, confirms the Report of the Ratification of the Treaty of Cession of the Florida’s to the United States.” Of the numberless rumours of this ratification which have swarmed for nearly the space of two years, this comes with the appearance of the greatest solidity— Yet that the first intelligence of so important an Event should come to us through London, Liverpool, and Charleston, is a presumption against its probability.

17. V: Heard Mr Ryland the Chaplain of the Senate, preach at the Capitol— His discourse was very long, declamatory and tedious— After Church, Dr Eustis spoke to me about the Missouri question, and told me that one or two pieces which have been published in the Boston Patriot, against the objections to the unqualified admission of that State, were written by General Dearborn the Son; now Collector of the Port of Boston— I paid visits to Mr and Mrs Silsbee at Miss Hyer’s on the Capitol Hill, and to Captain Tucker at Brown’s Hotel. He is applying for a pension by special act of Congress, and mentioned to me his motives, for asking it, which relate more to his family than to himself— There were visitors at our house; a young Mr Ogle, a nephew of Mrs Tayloe’s, and an acquaintance of Fanny Johnson’s—Miss S. Forrest, and Dr Thornton. There is an unusual portion of sickness among the members of Congress, and this evening Nathanael Hazard a Representative from Rhode-Island died.

18. V:15.Mr Baring, a Son of Alexander Baring of London, brought me a Letter of Introduction from his father. He arrived, a few days since from England, at New-York— Young Labouchère his Cousin who was here last winter is now with him— These young men, when I was last in England were boys— Baring was at school at Geneva— Mr Sanderson came to the Office. He has undertaken the publication of a Biography of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, and has repeatedly applied to me to furnish him a life of my father. He came now to bring the first volume which contains a preliminary discourse, and a life of John Hancock— I made a number of enquiries of Mr Sanderson to ascertain the principles upon which this work will be conducted, and how far the proper sources of information have been explored— I asked him whether the lives, were to be panegyrics, or historical biographies— The applications have been to the families of each individual, who will furnish what materials they please, and whose contributions to the biographies will be tainted at least with all the partialities of friendship. I asked him if the dissensions and antagonisms of all these Patriots among themselves—their mutual oppositions and animosities, their errors and their views were to be included in the narratives of their lives— He was not very well prepared to answer these questions— He did not exactly know how the work would be conducted— I asked him who was to furnish the life of Samuel Chase. He believed that was not settled. At this I expressed some surprize; and enquired whether the publishers of the work were aware how conspicuous that name ought to
be in the Catalogue of the Signers of the Declaration. He said that application had been made to his family for access to his papers, but they had no papers, that could be applied with any use to this purpose— I told him I considered Mr Chase as one of the men whose life conduct and opinions had been of the most extensive influence upon the Constitution of this Country. He not only signed the Declaration of Independence, but was an active and distinguished member of the Congress during the early and most critical period of the Revolution— He was a man of ardent passions, of strong mind, of domineering temper— His life was consequently turbulent and boisterous. He had for some years almost uncontrouled dominion over the politics of the State of Maryland. At other times, unpopular in the extreme—and was more than once impeached— Appointed by President Washington, one of the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States, he had continued in that office upwards of twenty years, until his death— He was the only judge of that Court who had ever been impeached— His impeachment had settled some principles and some practice of our Constitutional Law. But he himself as a judge had settled others of the highest importance; one of them in my opinion of very pernicious importance— He decided as I think directly in the face of an Amendatory Article of the Constitution of the United States (the seventh) that this Union in its federative capacity has no common Law— A decision which has crippled the powers not only of the judiciary, but of all the Departments of the National Government— The reasons upon which he rested that decision are not sound; but as they flattered the popular prejudices, it has remained unreversed to this day. Mr Chase’s life is among those which if historically written, will be of the highest interest, and may give occasion to the freest and most useful discussion— Sanderson said the intention was to write the lives freely, but not controversially. He was however convinced of the importance of the views I had taken of the life of Mr Chase. Mr Canning came, and occupied the remaining Office hours till six. His principal object was to have further conversation upon the subject of the Slave-trade— On the fourth of this Month a Resolution passed the House of Representatives on the motion of C. F. Mercer calling upon the President for copies of the Correspondence, with any of the foreign maritime powers relating to the Slave-trade— Mr Canning now reminded me, that in some of our former Conversations, I had told him that after the meeting of Congress; when there would be opportunities for consulting the opinions of members, the President would again take into consideration the proposals of the British Government, and determine upon some proposal to be offered in its stead, if he should finally consider it as inadmissible. I told him that there was no change in the President’s opinions concerning the British proposals, but if he would write me a note referring to them, they would be deliberately considered, and a written answer given; after which both papers would be communicated with the answer to the call from the House of Representatives— Our conversation also diverged upon the trial of the Queen, and the part which Mr George Canning has taken in that affair, which I thought very creditable to him: and also to the aspect of political affairs in Europe, arising from the recent Revolutions in Spain, Naples and Portugal. Upon all this Mr Canning was cautious to avoid expressing any opinion of his own; but he told me that his Cousin upon differing with his Colleagues, in relation to the prosecution of the Queen had tendered his resignation to the king, who had declined accepting it— The funeral of Mr Hazard was this day, but I could not attend it.

19. V:30. I was part of the morning at the War Office with Major Roberdeau remeasuring the French Metre and the depth and Diameter of the Litre, upon Troughton’s scale. The result of the admeasurement of the Metre, agrees more exactly with the last of Captain Kater, than with any other of the admeasurements which had been made before— I also called upon Mr Calhoun the Secretary of War and requested him to have a copy of the map lent me by Mr Torres, which he promised. Mr Torres himself called at the Office and left a long Note with seven enclosed documents, relating to the proposals lately made by the Spanish General Morrillo to the Colombian Government, and
Generals— Torres complains of it, as insidious on the part of the Spanish Government, because the same proposals were made at the same time, to the Congress, and to several commanding Generals at a great distance from me another with the intention of producing dissension between them; but on the second of November last the Government at Angostura issued a new declaration confirming that of Independence of 1811. and Mr Torres by order of his Government informs me that they have determined to carry on the war, without intermission— Torres told me that he had Letters from some American Members of the Cortes at Madrid, dated the first days of October, and informing him that the Florida Treaty would be ratified— Mr Clagett the member of the House of Representatives from New-Hampshire came again to urge the nomination of his Son as District Attorney, for that State; and he now brings a Letter from George Sullivan the Attorney General of the State, expressing the opinion that Humphreys, from his advanced age is not competent to perform the duties of the Office— This day Mr Eustis offered to the House of Representatives, his Resolution for admitting conditionally the State of Missouri into the Union— The President also transmitted to the House of Representatives a Message with a Report and documents, relating to the progress of the Commissions under the 5th. 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent; in answer to a call from the House, on the 21st. of November last upon the motion of R. C. Mallary a Member from Vermont— This is one of the cases in which secret motives are operating upon public principles and events— Mrs Adams’s weekly tea-party was this Evening numerously attended— There was music, and dancing, with the Piano.

20. VI:Coll. Samuel D. Harris of Boston called at the Office— He has been sent here as the Messenger with votes of the Electors of President and Vice-President for the State of Massachusetts. Mr J. J. Wilson a Senator from New-Jersey came with an application for a pardon of Clintock a man convicted of piracy and reprieved. Upon his testimony, corroborated by circumstancial evidence of great force rest suspicions of the blackest hue against the Collector of Savannah, and other persons of high-standing there. I have been endeavouring more than a year to obtain a thorough scrutiny into this affair; but hitherto with little effect— Clintock cannot be released until, it shall be determined whether the Bulloch’s shall or shall not be prosecuted. Mr Butler and Mr Livermore members of the House of Representatives from New Hampshire came to recommend the nomination of young Clagett as district Attorney in the room of Humphreys. They came at the solicitation of Clagett the father, to certify the incompetency of Humphreys, which neither of them however very positively did— Butler inferred it from his age, and from opinions of others, without knowing any thing from which he could be warranted in inferring it himself— Livermore had not been for the last six years in the way of witnessing the official transactions of Mr Humphreys, nor had even seen him— He could not testify to his incompetency when he had known him; but a difference of six years, after a man has reached 74 or 75 may be supposed to have produced infirmity of body and mind. Dr Morse likewise called, and is about to return to New-Haven— Mr Canning sent me a note upon the Slave-trade in consequence of the Conversation relating to that subject between us the day before yesterday— I took it to the President, who determined to have a Cabinet Consultation concerning it. Mrs Adams was quite ill this day— Jesse Slocumb a Member of the House of Representatives from North-Carolina died of a pleurisy.

21. V:Mr Josiah Meigs, the Commissioner of the land Office, brought me an answer from one of the Surveyors general, to some enquiries I had requested to make, concerning the Standard Chains used for surveying the Lands of the United States which are offered for sale— The Law required that a special Standard should be made, and there was one, but it does not appear that it is now in use, nor what has become of it. William Lee was at the Office— Also Mr Richards a member of the House of Representatives from
Vermont, and Mr Sanford a Senator from New-York. Richards came to speak of the proceedings in the House of Representatives in relation to the Commission under the 5th: Article of the Treaty of Ghent. He hinted, that these proceedings were influenced more by personal motives and private passions than by public purposes— He appeared to be particularly concerned, on account of Mr Bradley the Agent who is a kinsman of his— Mr Sanford’s object was an enquiry, concerning the actual state of our commercial negotiation with France. On returning home to dine, I found my Sons George and John had just arrived from Cambridge— They come to spend the Winter vacation with us— We had been anxious for their arrival, having a journey of 500 miles to perform at this Season— We had company to dinner, Mr Crawford the Secretary of the Treasury Messrs.Chandler of Maine, R. M. Johnson of Kentucky, R. King of New-York, Mills of Massachusetts and Walker of Georgia, Senators, and Messrs.Brush, of Ohio and Gorham of Massachusetts, members of the House of Representatives— There had also been invited MrPleasants, Senator from Virginia, Mr Brown of Kentucky, Cannon of Tennessee, Garnett and Jackson of Virginia, F. Johnson of Kentucky, Smith of North-Carolina, and Street of New-York, members of the House, and Mr Crawford, Secretary of the Treasury, and MrCheves, President of the Bank of the United States— Mr Cheves, who had been some days in the City upon business sent an excuse, being obliged to return to Philadelphia— Mr Crawford and Mr Pleasants, accepted but sent excuses this morning; slight indisposition and the weather— The members of the house were almost all detained by their attendance upon the funeral of Mr Slocumb— More than half our company thus failed us, and we had a very thin party at table— In the Evening all the family except my Sons attended a Ball at Mr Wirt’s.

22. VI:30.Captain Tucker came this morning and took leave; being on his departure to return home. I had also a visit from a Mr Shaw; and from young Bourne, the Son of the late Sylvanus Bourne, so long Consul at Amsterdam. He says his brother is with General Devereux, fighting for the Independence of the South Americans, of the Republic of Colombia. This is better than hereditary dependence upon the public for bread— I accompanied Mr Roth, the Chargé d’Affaires of France to a private Audience of the President, at which he delivered a Letter from the King of France, announcing the birth of a Son to the Duchess de Berri, to whom he had given the title of Duke of Bordeaux— This is the long expected and important child, who in the silly creed of the Bourbonites is to preserve the crown of France in the line of that exemplary personage Louis the fifteenth— This child is to be the infrangible curb to the revolutionary licentiousness of the age, and to secure possession by right divine to the throne of the lilies, for a succession of generations. How many of these children of hope, and joy and promise have I seen, turn in the lapse of years to children of misery, desolation and despair. The Duke of Bordeaux is a rattle, for the great children of the Bourbon race, but it would require more than powers of prophecy to foretell that he will ever be king of France— I dined this day with Johnson Hellen at Mr Calhoun’s, with a party of men, Mrs Calhoun being the only Lady at table. In the Evening I attended with all the family a Ball at Captain Thompson’s— There was introduced to me there a young man by the name of Martin, a lawyer from Frederick said to be a suitor of Fanny Johnson’s; and very apparently assuming to have claims upon her. The company was numerous. I played Chess with Mrs. Freeman— It was near midnight when we came home.

23. VII: There were a succession of members of Congress this morning at the Office— And at one O’Clock, a meeting of the members of the administration at the President’s, to consider the proposals in the note of the 20th. respecting the Slave-trade received from Mr Canning. The British proposals are that the several powers which have enacted Laws for the abolition of the Slave trade, should agree that the Ships of War which each of them may station upon the African Coast, to intercept vessels carrying on the trade under its own flag, should have the right to search vessels sailing under other flags; and if upon such search, Slaves should be found on board the vessel, to seize her and carry her into some port or place in Africa, to be tried by a mixed Court of two judges, one belonging to each of the two Nations, and two arbitrators, one of which also, from each of the two Nations; to be called in, upon any difference of opinion
between the judges. The British Government have by treaties obtained the consent of Portugal, Spain and the Netherlands, to this system, and they are using every exertion with unwearied importunity to obtain the assent to it, of all the great European Powers, and of the United States— They pressed it, at the Congress of Aix-La-Chapelle upon France, Russia, Austria and Prussia, neither of whom however agreed to it— The refusal of France was explicit and very decisive—supported by spirited and cogent reasoning. The present British Ministers, who care little about it themselves, are pressed by the party of the Saints in Parliament, and therefore, wherever they meet resistance to their proposal urge it with the more apparent earnestness— It has been repeatedly rejected by the Government of the United States— It was now considered again— The opinion was unanimous that we could consent to no such tribunal for the trial of Citizens of the United States— That it would be repugnant to the Article in the Constitution, concerning the organization of the judicial power— That there is no authority given by the Constitution to establish such Courts; and that the mode of trial without grand or petit juries would be alike repugnant to the 5th. and 6th. Articles amendatory to the Constitution—all which I have repeatedly alledged to Mr Canning. On the question relative to the other point; granting mutual right of search Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Navy had some doubts— He was not so clear in the principle of persisting to refuse it. He did not think it would give any countenance to the British practice of impressing men from our merchant vessels in time of War— He thought there was very little analogy between the two cases— That this mutual right of search, for the particular purpose of suppressing this trade would undoubtedly be an expedient highly efficacious to the attainment of the end— That by declining it, we shall expose ourselves to the imputation of unsincerity, as to our purpose of suppressing the trade, and that the British Government would avail itself of it to discredit us with the rest of Europe. That there was a strong feeling, and anxious desire among the people of this Country for the suppression of the trade and some discontent at the notorious fact that all the measures hitherto taken have proved insufficient. If therefore the arrangement could be so made that vessels under our flag should be brought for trial into our own jurisdiction, and tried by our own Courts, he inclined to think that the mutual right of search and seizure might be agreed to— Mr Calhoun the Secretary at War, strongly expressed the contrary opinion— He said he gave no credit to Great-Britain, for her extreme ardour in this cause of abolition— He thought her professions of benevolence merely ostensible— Her real motives, were her own interest, and ambition. After having prohibited the traffic by her own people she had a most powerful individual interest against its being carried on by others. Her Colonial, her commercial, her shipping interests were all deeply affected by it. They could not bear to see a profitable trade enjoyed by rivals, and competitors, in which they were not permitted to share, themselves. Then this right of searching foreign ships was precisely the thing upon which she was at issue with us on the impressment question. It exactly suited her views to devise an expedient under colour of its necessity for suppressing the Slave-trade, which should familiarize other commercial and navigating Nations, to the practise of submitting to the search of foreign armed ships— All this was to pass to the account of benevolence and humanity. At the same time if we accede to this proposal, the credit of it all goes to her— We follow her lead— We appear to the world, as the Satellite, and she the primary planet; a position the more disparaging to us, because in point of fact she was merely following our lead; the first example of prohibiting the trade having been set by us. I concurred generally with these views of Mr Calhoun, adding that with regard to the motives of the British Government, I was rather more charitable— I believed the Ministers themselves were not very earnest for the abolition of the trade— But there was a powerful Party in Parliament, and in the Nation who had set their hearts upon it. The Ministers were obliged to conciliate them. I believed great multitudes of this party were honestly, and disinterestedly actuated by real motives
of humanity— I gave credit even to the Ministers for some part of this motive— The impulses to action in this as in most other cases are not simple but compounded— I would not deny the existence of those that are laudable, nor neglect the detection of those which co-operate with them— The President said that whatever the motives of the British Government might be, our refusal to accede in this case to the mutual right of search and seizure, would hereafter strengthen our cause, in any discussion with them upon the question of search for men, during war. This alone was he thought a decisive reason for persevering in our refusal— But Mr Canning’s note required proposals to be made on our part, if we declined those presented to us— What should we offer?— Several expedients were proposed— One was a stipulation to keep a certain force constantly on the Coast of Africa, and in the latitudes where the trade is chiefly carried on— But it was concluded that this might become inconvenient, and even useless. It was finally thought best not to propose any formal convention; but to state the fact that we have had for some time a vessel constantly cruizing on that Coast, and that it was intended to keep such force there. That by concert with the British Government, instructions might mutually be given to the Commanders of these Cruizers on both sides, to cruize in company, whenever they might find it useful or convenient, and to furnish one another, every aid and assistance in their power, for the furtherance of the common object— I was directed to prepare the draft of an answer to Mr Canning’s note, conformable to this determination— It was near five O’Clock, when the Cabinet Meeting broke up— I was belated therefore, in going to Mr Poletica, the Russian Minister’s to dine— I found the company already seated at dinner. It was his anniversary banquet to the diplomatic corps, on the Emperor’s birth-day— This day instead of to-morrow which will be Sunday— The Emperor Alexander’s and the President’s healths were as usual toasted in Champagne. I retired immediately after dinner and spent the Evening with all our family at W. S. Smith’s.

24. VI:30. Heard at the Capitol, Mr Campbell the Chaplain to the house of Representatives— His text was from Numbers XXIV:17. “I shall see him but not now; I shall behold him but not nigh: there shall come a Star out of Jacob, and a Sceptre shall rise out of Israel”—the remaining words of the verse were omitted; they are “and shall smite the corners of Moab, and destroy all the children of Sheth.[”] These latter words would not so well have suited as the others for a Christmas sermon. For this it was intended, but with it was also mixed up a commentary upon the wonderful and inexhaustible Story of Balaam. After Church I paid a visit at O’Neal’s Hotel to young Baring and Labouchère, and was so long with them that it left me no time to pay any other visits before dinner. I spent the Evening in my chamber with my Son George, in such conversation as might enable me to form some estimate of his proficiency in his studies.

25. VII: Christmas day. No Attendance at the Office— I gave the day to relaxation, and with a view to make an experiment upon the taste of the younger part of our present family, after breakfast, I read aloud Pope’s Messiah, a poem suited to the day, and of which my own admiration was great at an earlier age than that of my Son Charles, the youngest person now in my family. Not one of them, excepting George appeared to take the slightest interest in it, nor is there one of them who has any relish for literature. Charles has a great fondness for books, and a meditative mind, but neither disposition nor aptitude for public speaking, or correct reading— Charles must teach himself all that he learns— He will learn nothing from others— Literature has been the charm of my life, and could I have carved out my own fortunes, to Literature would my whole life have been devoted. I have been a lawyer for bread, and a Statesman at the call of my Country— In the practice of the Law, I never should have attained the highest eminence, for the want of natural and spontaneous eloquence. The operations of my mind are slow; my imagination sluggish, and my powers of extemporaneous speaking very insufficient— But I have much capacity for and love of labour—
habits, on the whole of industry and temperance, and a strong and almost innate passion for literary pursuits. The business and sometimes the dissipations of my life have in a great measure withdrawn me from it— The summit of my ambition would have been by some great work of literature to have done honour to my age and Country, and to have lived in the gratitude of future ages— This consummation of happiness has been denied me— The portion of life allotted to me, is that of my mortal existence—but even in this failure of my highest objects, literature has been to me a source of continual enjoyment and a powerful preservative from vice— It would have been a great comfort to me, if all or either of my children inherited this propensity— George is not entirely without it— The others have it not; and I have found every effort to stimulate them to it, hitherto fruitless— Pope says t’is Education forms the common mind; and so it is; but the common mind will be always groveling in common objects— The uncommon mind must form itself— We all dined this day at Mr Frye’s—Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were also there. Some of the incidents of the day were not pleasing to me. After dinner I diverted my thoughts by a game of Chess with Smith.

26. VI:30.James Burrill junr. a Senator from the State of Rhode-Island died this day. He was one of the most useful and respectable members of that body and alike estimable both in his public and private character. This third case of death among the members of Congress in the course of ten days, has occasioned much alarm among the timid and valetudinarian of their colleagues. Some of them are disposed to draw conclusions of unhealthiness in the place, which are without foundation. The place has all the healthiness of a rural situation of land waving in hill and dale, of running waters, and briskly circulating winds— Mr Francis Johnson a member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky came with a remonstrance signed by a great number of persons against the superseding of the Newspaper at Russelville for printing the Laws. I told Coll. Johnson that the responsibility of this alteration must rest upon his kinsman and namesake the Senator, at whose instance alone, it had been made. He said that it was personally to him a subject of perfect indifference— He had no wish that the printer at Russelville should be preferred; but as the remonstrants were his Constituents he was obliged to deliver to me their representation. But he said he would answer them that the reason for the change, had been a more convenient location for the distribution of the Laws, and there would be no necessity that I should answer the memorial at-all. I told him I should answer it, and state that the change had been made at the desire of Coll. R. M. Johnson, that being the simple fact, and my principle for complying with his wish having been my confidence in his knowledge, of that distribution of the printing which would best suit the local interest of the State— Major Roberdeau came by appointment to the Office and we weighed with all possible accuracy the contents in various kinds of water of the French Standard Litres— There was a difference amounting to nearly a penny weight, between the contents of the two— That which I have already tried containing so much more than the other— Major Roberdeau had procured for me a large jug full of distilled water which together with the other kinds of water that I had has been several days in the Library room to acquire the same temperature as that of the room— They were all at 32.5 or just above the freezing point. The Litre and glass weighed 4 pounds 6 ounces 12 pennyweights Troy; or 26208 Grains— And it is a circumstance worthy of remark, that upon four weighings on as many different days this is the second time that they have shewn this result; while at one weighing they were four grains and at another eight grains heavier. Whether this difference was in the things, and resulted from that in the state of the atmosphere, or whether it was inaccuracy in the scales, or imperfection in the mode of weighing I know not, but it proves how exceedingly difficult it is to ascertain with perfect exactness quantities comparatively so minute— On weighing the different
kinds of water we found the Litre contained 15402 grains of distilled water 15403 of river water 15406 of pump, and 15407 of rain water, a result singularly favourable to the purity both of the Spring and river water of this place— I therefore set it down from the average of all my experiments that the French standard Litre contains 15405 grains of rain water—without allowance for the weight of the excluded air. I called at the President’s with the draft of an answer to Mr Canning’s last Note on the Slave-trade— He took it for consideration— Mrs Adams had her weekly tea-party, which was thinly attended— I received an invitation to attend the funeral of Mr Burrill: to go from the Senate chamber to-morrow morning.

27. VI:30. Attended the funeral of Mr Burrill, which proceeded from the Senate chamber at 11. O’Clock this morning— There was a prayer before the procession moved by the chaplain of the Senate Mr Ryland. I met Mr Calhoun at the Senate-chamber and he rode with me— The burying ground at the Navy-yard is the spot where all the members of Congress, dying here and not removed by their friends are interred— After the ceremony was over, Mr Calhoun rode with me, and I left him at the War-Office. We were remarking upon the number of members of Congress, already mingling with the dust of this region, among whom are the two successive Vice-President’s George Clinton; and Elbridge Gerry. There are plain, modest and tasteless marble monuments over their remains, which the lapse of a few short years will demolish— We were remarking how exclusively by the nature and genius of our institutions, we confine all our thoughts and cares to present time— We have neither fore-fathers nor posterity— This burying yard, is remote from any Church— The funeral is a mere commitment of earth to earth— There is nothing to sooth the afflicted, or to rouse the thoughtless, by the promise, and the warning which a Church would give of the connection between time and eternity— Nothing to remind the attendant at the funeral that death is a transition from this to another world. There is a Resolution of Congress, existing ever since the death of Washington, that a monument in honour of his memory, should be erected— I said to Calhoun, that I thought under that Resolution Congress ought to build a Church of durable Stone; equal in dimensions to Westminister Abbey, or the Pantheon at Paris— That sheltered under the roof and within the walls of this Church, should be the sepulchral monument of Washington; and around it, suitably disposed, those of the Statesmen and Legislators of this Union, whose lives may from time to time, honourably close during their attendance here on the service of their Country. Mr. Calhoun thought that Congress would not be supported in the expence of such a measure, by the public opinion; of which I am well aware. He observed that it would be of great advantage to this Country, to have Statesmen of a philosophical turn of mind. He is himself of that character and it has brought him to high distinction at a very early age. But he is the only man of the present administration, who does possess it. We are obliged to live from hand to mouth; to provide for the day that is passing over us, and to leave posterity to take care of itself— After I returned to the Office D. P. Cook of Illinois called there— He came to enquire concerning a set of the Laws of the United States of Bioren’s Edition for some person entitled to them. The President’snephew, Lieutt. Monroe came to ask my opinion of the propriety of superseding the Drawing Room this Evening, on account of the death so recently of three members of Congress— I thought it would be advisable, if such general notice could be given, that the persons who usually attend, may not go to the house at the hour, and not otherwise— Notice was afterwards sent me, that the drawing-room would not be held.

28. IV:15. It was a day of Snow and Rain. I dined at the British Minister, Mr Canning’s, with all the members of the diplomatic and Consular corps now residing here. Canning resides in the house formerly occupied by the late Spanish Minister Onis, and has very lately got his establishment settled— I retired soon after dinner, and went to Captain Thompson’s, for Fanny Johnson who had dined there. I found Mr Martin was the only person not of the family besides Fanny— She told me as we were returning home, that Martin
had not dined there, but had come in shortly before I did. She also said that Martin was a young lawyer of respectable connections, a son of judge Martin of the Eastern Shore of Maryland— The fact is that Martin is a suitor of Fanny’s, disapproved by Mr Grahame, and all her connections— That he has followed her here from Frederick, and that her dinner this day at Captain Thompson’s was an interview managed for them by Cecilia Thompson the Captain’s daughter— Fanny Johnson is an uncommonly beautiful girl and of manners personally fascinating; but with little mind, and no cultivation— She says she would never wish to marry a man, unless she could respect his understanding; and this is what she probably thinks she admires in Martin, who with a mean personal figure, and no property has considerable pretensions to talents.

29. VII:30.Mr M’Lane, the old revolutionary Officer, now Collector of the Port of Wilmington in Delaware, and father of Louis M’Lane, one of the members of the House of Representatives from that State, called upon me this morning— He has business relating to his office to settle with the Treasury Department. I called at the President’s— Upon the draft of the Answer to Mr Canning’s last Note upon the Slave-trade, he desired me to notify a meeting of the members of the Administration for to-morrow at Noon. I was occupied at the Office in preparing an answer to a call from the House of Representatives for any information received by the department of State, touching any alterations in the commercial laws or regulations of any of the Nations of Europe, since the year 1817. This resolution passed the House on the 11th. instt. on the motion of Mr Baldwin of Pennsylvania, the champion of the manufacturing interest. I told him the other day that the information required by the House, was contained chiefly in about half a dozen new Tariffs, in as many different languages, each a little volume— This will not answer his purpose, which he told me was only to shew, that there had been no relaxation in the restrictions of any European Nation, upon their commerce with the United States.

30. V:30.William Plumer junr. of New-Hampshire, and General S. Smith of Maryland, members of the House of Representatives, called this morning, successively at my Office. Plumer’s object was to express the wish for the re-appointment of Mr Humphreys as District Attorney for New-Hampshire. He hinted that there was personal and party feeling concerned in the efforts for the removal of Humphreys, as well as in those made at the commencement of the Session, to have the printing of the Laws of the Union transferred from the New-Hampshire Patriot, to another paper. Plumer is the Son of my old friend and once fellow Senator— The son, is one of the most promising young men now in public life— There was a Meeting of the Members of the Administration at the President’s, when my draft of an Answer to Mr Canning upon the Slave-trade note, was fully considered— Its principles had all been agreed to at the former meeting; and now the draft was approved with the suggestion of some slight alterations, and some omissions, to soften the harshness of refusal. I had drawn the paper in terms of the strongest characters with a view to leave no occasion for further discussion upon the subject. The consequence had been that the same Sentiment was expressed in the draft two or three times. It was proposed to curtail it of its repetitions, and of some expressions which might be offensive; to which I agreed. There was some deliberation upon the proposals to be offered instead of those from Great-Britain which we decline. That the draft was merely to concert between the two Governments mutual Instructions to the Commanders of the Cruizers upon the African Coast, that they may cruize in company, and otherwise render each other every assistance in their power towards the attainment of the common object— This may be done, without any formal Treaty stipulation; but the question was made, whether we might not offer further, an engagement by Treaty to keep a certain force, without intermission, say two or three armed vessels always cruizing on the coast. But Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Navy, said that we were not suffi-
ciently informed of the kind of force which might most usefully be employed upon that coast. Smaller vessels, drawing less water than those we now have there may be found better adapted to the service. It was not until the present year that we had any force there; and much information might be expected from the reports of the Officers who have been and are now employed upon it— There might also be inconvenience in an engagement which would deprive us of the power of adapting the disposal of all our naval force to the exigencies of circumstances from time to time— We could not foresee how long any force might be necessary there— From the captures which have already taken place, it is probable that the use of our flag may be altogether abandoned by the Slave-traders. A compact to keep Cruizers, where they could effect nothing would be troublesome, and give dissatisfaction to our own people— To these objections, Mr Calhoun added one of a political, and more general nature— He was averse to any compact with Great Britain upon this subject; because he believed she was pursuing private ends upon pretences of public Spirit— We began and are pursuing a system of policy of our own for the suppression of the Slave-trade— While we keep that course we stand upon Independent ground—but of any compact, to which at the proposal of Great-Britain we might accede, we should bear the burden, and she would monopolize the credit— On these Considerations it was concluded to leave the proposals, as they were in my draft— I attended this Evening a Meeting of the Columbian Institute, a learned Society of which I have been more than three years a member, but the Meetings of which I have never before had leisure to attend.
