Mr Josiah Meigs, Commissioner of the land Office is the President— Asbury Dickins, a Clerk in the Treasury department, Secretary— There were not more than five or six members who attended— I was obliged to leave the Meeting before it broke up; but was placed upon a Committee for an application to Congress for a Lottery to raise funds for the benefit of the Society— This petition had been resolved upon at a former Meeting, but the Committee appointed to prepare it had not agreed upon their Report— Dr Thornton the Chairman had prepared one which was now recommitted with Instructions, at my instance, to report first whether any petition to Congress for a Lottery would be expedient; and if so, a new draft— This was agreed to, but I was immediately added to the Committee.

31. VII:15. Heard Mr Ryland, the Chaplain to the Senate, at the Capitol— His text was from Lament III:22 “It is of the Lord’s mercies, that we are not consumed, because his compassions fail not.” His eloquence does not please me. It is vehement in manner and empty of substance—less than ordinary thoughts in tumid and creeping language— His doctrines, are the common topics of Calvinism— It was remarked that he took no notice, by the most distant allusion, either in his prayers or Sermon, of the unexampled incident of the decease of three members of Congress within the space of ten days. After Church, I paid visits to N. Edwards, Senator from Illinois, and Isham Talbot from Kentucky— Edwards only was at home, and still confined to his chamber, though recovering— He renewed his complaints against the partialities of the President in favour of the enemies of his administration and adverse to its friends, especially in the appointments to Office in the Western Country— He spoke much also of the two Senators elected from Missouri, Barton and Benton, and was particularly anxious that a Mr Stewart should be appointed the District judge in Missouri, in preference to a Mr Gray— They have both been territorial judges, but Edwards says that both for character and talents, Stewart is by far the superior man. Benton however will strain every nerve for the appointment of Gray— I told Edwards that the third territorial judge John B. C. Lucas, was also a Candidate; but he said there could be no possible chance for him. Benton to be sure, would much rather it should be Stewart than Lucas, whose son he killed in a duel, but Lucas was too unpopular— He was a man of singular and repulsive manners, and his appointment would give satisfaction to no party. I did not enter into discussion with Mr Edwards upon this subject— Lucas will not be appointed, because he stands upon his own merits, and powerful interest is made in behalf of others. Gray will be appointed, because he is Benton’s man and because his influence will be backed by that of Mr Crawford— But Lucas would be the most suitable man for
the Office— His enemies are his virtues. He has resisted the depredators upon the Nation who swarm in that Country with fraudulent land-claims, and he has been of the party which would have left open a door for the possible future emancipation of Slaves. But he is a man of unimpeached integrity— Born in France; bred to the knowledge and practice of the Civil Law; many years settled in the United States; and having been sometime a Representative in Congress from one of the Districts of Pennsylvania. His misfortune has been in going to reside in a Country to the vices of which he could not accommodate his principles, and such is the Constitution of human nature, that virtue herself becomes obnoxious when she cannot adapt her principles to times and places— Edwards himself is a warm friend of the President’s— But there is a rivality of influence between him and his colleague Jesse B. Thomas in their State; and as Thomas is a partizan of Crawford’s, it provokes Edwards to see all the appointments by the General Government in the State bestowed upon Thomas’s creatures. He declared his determination to oppose in Senate the confirmation of some of these nominations— Mr Bailey paid us a visit.

Day. The range of my rising hour through the month has been from III:15 to VII:30. the average V:40. during the Session of Congress later Evenings always produce later Mornings— We have now a more numerous family than we had ever before been accustomed to— Our three Sons, Johnson and Mary Hellen, and Fanny Johnson, are all with us. Company at home and abroad absorbs much time and attention. Evening study has been abandoned, and become so irksome that I fear never to be able to resume it. My Office hours in spite of every exertion to change them remain as heretofore— From twelve or one, to five or six— The morning hours are necessary to me at my house; and if I go earlier to the Office, I still find it impossible to return earlier from it.

The year has perhaps been the most laborious one of my life. It has been without vacation, and that portion of the Summer and Autumn, which in the two preceding years, I had borrowed for a short visit to my nearest friends has been this year the most deeply engaged in the performance of public duties. Had I enjoyed my usual indulgence, it would not have been possible for me to have prepared the Report upon weights and measures, first required by a Resolution of the Senate of 3. March 1817. and again by a Resolution of the House of Representatives of 14. December 1819. On this I have been the last six Months constantly engaged, and the Report is not yet ready to be sent in. Neither am I satisfied with my own work as it must be sent in; but intend if the public should take any interest in it, to revise it, at a period of greater leisure— No incident of material importance has occurred in my family during the year, but there appears to be no reason to doubt that the Florida Treaty has been ratified by Spain— The state of my private affairs is less favourable than at the close of the last year, yet such as calls for unceasing effusions of gratitude to the giver of all good— At the Commencement of the Session of Congress, my Diary was already a week or ten days in arrear. I have since been unable to resume it. The difficulty of writing has much increased in the course of this year— It will probably be impossible for me to go through another year, with as much detail— I would fain continue it until the termination of my public service, which may continue, through the second Presidency of Mr Monroe— But I have no reason to flatter myself that the powers of my hand will hold out even one year longer— Thy will be done!

N.B. 16. April 1821. The arrears of the Diary continued through the Session of Congress, and until the 20th of March, when I resumed it, at the 7th. of November, since which thus far has been redeemed— Let me give the future to Hope.
